answer: Professors in introductory Engineering and Computational Sciences courses often have a big impact on students. They explain concepts clearly and encourage critical thinking and curiosity. Advising is very simple and easy. Everything is pretty straightforward and its pretty easy to get in contact with your advisors. Most professors and advisors are approachable and responsive, regularly meeting with students during office hours or over email. Many students say they wish they had reached out to professors sooner - faculty are approachable and eager to help.

Many Engineering and Computational Sciences courses are hands-on. Students regularly code and build projects, especially in advanced classes. Even theory-heavy courses tend to include practical components. Engineering and Computational Sciences seniors complete a semester-long capstone. Faculty propose project ideas, and students select one to develop and present.
Many professors have industry backgrounds and incorporate real-world examples and emerging technologies into their teaching.
Yes, theres an Honors Program for students seeking deeper academic challenges. Independent research and advanced electives are also available.

tag: Internships, Career Services, and Employment Outcomes
answer: Engineering and Computational Sciences students intern at software companies, engineering firms, research labs, local startups, and major organizations like Raytheon and Microsoft. The OBrien Center provides personalized resume reviews, mock interviews, and career fairs. Faculty also support students with feedback and opportunity recommendations. Warriors at Work is a career development initiative from the OBrien Center. Students can apply and learn more through their website or staff. Graduates have gone on to organizations like Microsoft and MITRE, or continued their education at schools such as Northeastern and UMass Amherst.

Students can join ongoing faculty research or start independent projects. Those who contribute meaningfully often co-author publications. Students can work with faculty on research over the summer, sometimes with stipends.

Engineering and Computational Sciences classes are typically small - around 15-25 students - allowing for more direct support and interaction with faculty. Tutoring is available through the Math Center and Peer Tutoring, especially for challenging courses like Data Structures and Circuits.

Most labs and makerspaces remain open in the evenings and on weekends, and students can access them with their Mack Cards. Engineering and Computational Sciences facilities include modern labs, a robotics lab, and a makerspace equipped with 3D printers and other tools.

Collaboration between CS and Engineering students is common, especially in research and clubs that combine coding and hardware. Interdisciplinary collaboration happens through innovation challenges, joint classes, and service projects across schools.

Clubs include SWE, Robotics, NSBE, Lets Innovate, the Computer Club, and others focused on tech and engineering interests. Most clubs meet weekly and are considerate of academic demands, helping students manage both involvement and schoolwork effectively. Merrimack hosts some events, and students also attend hackathons at nearby institutions for hands-on experience and networking. Students can take on leadership roles in clubs, guide team projects, or serve as peer mentors and tutors.
Undecided Engineering students take general courses that apply across majors. Advisors help them explore interests before choosing a specific path.

Most Engineering and Computational Sciences students walk or use the campus shuttle to travel between buildings. Most Engineering and Computational Sciences classes are held on the east side, while general education classes are typically located on the main campus. Housing is available on campus for all years, and off-campus apartments are located nearby for upperclassmen. Engineering and Computational Sciences students can eat at a smaller dining location on the Engineering and Computational Sciences side or at a food truck during warmer months, both accepting meal swipes.

Popular study spots include the second-floor lounge in the Engineering and Computational Sciences building, which is conveniently close to faculty offices. It varies. Many students study in groups for projects, while others prefer studying independently. The Engineering and Computational Sciences community is tight-knit and supportive. Students help one another, and faculty are genuinely invested in student success.

Students typically learn Java, Python, SQL, and sometimes JavaScript or C/C++, depending on the electives taken. Courses use tools like VSCode, GitHub, MATLAB, and more. Most instructors allow students to use any IDE as long as the work is completed correctly. Students are encouraged to build GitHub portfolios and some contribute to the colleges open-source utilities.

tag: Cultural Adaptation and Support for Underrepresented Students
answer: There are orientation programs, and the campus community is generally welcoming and eager to learn about different cultures and experiences. Programs like Compass and mentoring initiatives through academic departments and the OBrien Center support underrepresented students.

Students can study abroad during the summer or semester, and some Engineering and Computational Sciences students participate in engineering service trips through the SEND Program. The SEND Program offers service trips during breaks where students volunteer in U.S. and international communities, focusing on social justice and personal growth.

Tuition is managed through the Bursars Office, and students can set up payment plans through the college portal. Students can contact the Financial Aid Office or visit the Merrimack website under Scholarships & Aid. Deposits are made through the Admissions Portal. The Admissions Office on the main campus is available to assist if needed.

tag: Student Life - Challenges, Reasons for Choosing Merrimack, and Favorite Aspects
answer: Balancing coursework and managing time is often a challenge at first, but support systems are in place to help. Students often cite small class sizes, early research opportunities, and a strong support system as key reasons. The strong sense of community. Students appreciate being recognized and having close connections with professors and peers.

First-year Engineering and Computational Sciences students have access to special programs like the First-Year Experience (FYE) course, which helps with academic skills, career planning, and adjusting to college life. Peer mentors and orientation leaders are available to guide students during their transition. Faculty advisors are also assigned early on to help plan course schedules and answer questions.

The Hamel Health Center offers medical services, counseling, and wellness programming. Students can schedule appointments for physical and mental health services. Counseling support is free, and the college regularly hosts events promoting mental well-being, like stress relief days and therapy dog visits.

A typical day might include a mix of lectures, lab sessions, and study blocks. Engineering and Computational Sciences classes usually run between 8:00 AM and 6:00 PM, with gaps for meals, studying, and club meetings. Labs are often scheduled in the afternoons and can last a few hours. Students usually balance classes, homework, group meetings, and time to relax.

Merrimack automatically considers admitted students for merit scholarships based on academic achievements. Additional scholarships may be available based on financial need, special interests, or participation in programs like Honors. Students can also apply for external scholarships and research assistantships once enrolled.

Students have access to the Merrimack Athletics Complex (MAC), fitness classes, club sports, and intramural leagues. There is a large gym, indoor track, pool, and courts available. Even non-athletes can join fitness classes like yoga, Zumba, or lifting programs.

tag: Weather and Seasonal Life on Campus
answer: Merrimack experiences all four seasons. Fall is beautiful with colorful leaves, winters can bring snow and cold temperatures, spring brings mild weather and flowers, and summers are warm. Students typically layer up in winter and take advantage of indoor study spaces. Snow events are handled efficiently, and the campus community stays active all year.

Joining clubs, participating in Welcome Week events, and living on campus are some of the easiest ways to make friends. Many students meet people through classes, shared study spaces, and group projects. The college encourages involvement and offers leadership workshops and social events year-round.

On weekends, students often attend campus events, participate in club activities, study, or explore the surrounding area. Merrimack is close to Boston, beaches, and hiking trails. Students can take campus shuttles, carpool, or use the commuter rail to go into the city. The local area also offers shopping, restaurants, and entertainment.

First-year students typically live in residence halls with roommates assigned based on a questionnaire about living habits. Upperclassmen can live in suites, apartments, or off-campus housing nearby. There are Living Learning Communities (LLCs) for students who want to live with peers who share similar interests.

Engineering and Computational Sciences students often find success by using planners, scheduling their study time, and setting priorities early on. Professors understand that students are involved in multiple activities and encourage communication if conflicts arise. Campus resources like the Academic Success Center offer time management workshops.

Commuters are a big part of the Merrimack community. There are commuter lounges on campus where students can study, relax, and store personal items. Commuters often stay involved through clubs, events, and academic support programs. Parking permits are available and the shuttle system makes getting around campus easy.

Merrimack offers more than just academic clubs - there are social clubs, cultural organizations, service groups, and recreational clubs. From theater productions and dance teams to business clubs and gaming groups, there is something for everyone. Students are encouraged to explore and join multiple groups.

Merrimack hosts many fun traditions throughout the year, like Homecoming, Macktoberfest, Springapalooza, and Midnight Madness. Events usually feature free food, games, and activities. Both commuters and residents get involved. There are also guest speakers, concerts, and charity events.

tag: Eating on Campus (Lunch and Casual Dining)
answer: Besides the main dining hall, students often grab food from Sparkys Place, The Warriors Den, Dunkin, or food trucks on campus. Meal plans cover most locations, and points can be used for extra flexibility. There are spots to eat near both the Engineering side and the main campus.

tag: School Spirit, Athletics, and Game Attendance
answer: Even if you arent an athlete, going to games is a big part of campus life. Hockey games at Lawler Arena are especially popular and often free or discounted for students. Merrimack has Division One sports teams, and many students attend games together to support the Warriors.

tag: Involvement for New Students (Finding Your Place)
answer: It can seem overwhelming at first, but new students quickly find their place. Welcome Week activities, club fairs, and social events are designed to help everyone connect. Joining even one club or attending a few events makes it much easier to make friends and get comfortable.
